questions.text: Which amongst the following is an example of autosomal dominant syndrome?
questions.solution: Reference: (Robbins Basic Pathology, 10th ed, Pg-246)

questions.text: How much time will it take for the interstitial infiltration of neutrophils (morphological change) in a patient suffering myocardial infarction?
questions.solution:
Myocardial infarction (MI), also commonly referred to as 'heart attack', is necrosis of the heart muscle resulting from ischemia.


Reference: (Robbins Basic Pathology, 10th ed, Pg-414)

choices.text: Increase in cell size and number
Increase in cell size without increase in number
Increase in cell number without increase in size
Increase in cell size and decrease in number

questions.text: In comparison to hyperplasia, hypertrophy involves-
questions.solution:
Hypertrophy is an increase in the size of cells resulting in an increase in the size of the organ. Hyperplasia is an increase in the number of cells in an organ that stems from increased proliferation, either of differentiated cells or, in some instances, less differentiated progenitor cells.

Reference: (Robbins Basic Pathology,10th ed, Pg-49-50)

questions.text: Epithelial granuloma is caused by-
questions.solution:
A granuloma is a focus of chronic inflammation consisting of a microscopic aggregation of macrophages that are transformed into epithelium like cells (epitheloid) surrounded by a callor of mononuclear leucocytes, principally lymphocytes and ocassionally plasma cells.

Immune granuloma (most common) is a type IV hypersensitivity that involved CD-4 helper T cell.

Reference: (Anderson Pathology,10th ed, Pg-583)

questions.text: IL-2 is secreted by-
questions.solution:
Interlukein - 2 Produced by activated T cells(CD-4)

Major functions:

  • Promotes growth and differentiation of T1 and B cells.
  • Stimulates cytotoxic T cells and NK cells.
  • Stimulates the secretion of the lymphokines.

Reference: (Ananthanarayan, 7th ed, Pg-144)

questions.text: Which of the following procedures is done as a routine technique for karyotyping using light microscopy?
questions.solution:
A karyotype is a photographic representation of a stained metaphase spread in which the chromosomes are arranged in order of decreasing length. A variety of techniques for staining chromosomes has been developed. With the widely used Giemsa stain (G banding) technique, each chromosome set can be seen to possess a distinctive pattern of alternating light and dark bands of variable widths. The use of banding techniques allows identification of each chromosome, and can detect and localize structural abnormalities large enough to produce changes in banding pattern.

C banding demonstrates heterochromatin.

Q banding demonstrates bands along chromosome.

R banding demonstrates pattern opposite to G banding.

Reference: (Robbins Basic Pathology, 10th ed, Pg-262)

questions.text: Tumour containing cells of all three germ layers is called-
questions.solution:
Teratoma is a special type of mixed tumor that contains recognizable mature or immature cells or tissues derived from more than one germ cell layer, and sometimes all three. Teratomas originate from totipotential germ cells such as those that normally reside in the ovary and testis and that are sometimes abnormally present in midline embryonic rests. Germ cells have the capacity to differentiate into any of the cell types found in the adult body; not surprisingly, therefore, they may give rise to neoplasms that contain elements resembling bone, epithelium, muscle, fat, nerve, and other tissues, all thrown together in a helterskelter fashion.

Reference: (Robbins Basic Pathology, 10th ed, Pg-191)

questions.text: Which is pulseless disease?
questions.solution:
Takayasu arteritis is a granulomatous vasculitis of medium- and large-sized arteries characterized principally by ocular disturbances and marked weakening of the pulses in the upper extremities (hence the alternate name, pulseless disease). This disorder manifests with transmural scarring and thickening of the aorta-particularly the aortic arch and great vessels-with severe luminal narrowing of the major branch vessels.

Reference: (Robbins Basic Pathology, 10th ed, Pg-385)

questions.text: Which worm causes myocarditis?
questions.solution:
Myocarditis encompasses a diverse group of clinical entities in which infectious agents and/or inflammatory processes target the myocardium.

In myocarditis, the inflammatory process is the cause of injury and not response to injury.

Most common cause of myocarditis is viral infection called coxackieviruses.

Trichinosis is the most common helminthic disease causing myocarditis.

Reference:(Robbins Basic Pathology, 8th ed, Pg-578)

questions.text: Spherocytosis of RBC's is a common feature in-
questions.solution:
G6PD deficiency is associated with transient episodes of intravascular hemolysis caused by exposure to an environmental factor (usually infectious agents or drugs) that produces oxidant stress.

Reference: (Robbins Basic Pathology, 8th ed, Pg-450)

questions.text: Schilling test is false positive in?
questions.solution:
The schilling test is a medical investigation used in patients with vitamin B12 deficiency. The purpose of the test is to determine if the patient has pernicious anemia.

In renal insufficiency, kidney is not able to excrete vitamin B12 and urine will have <5% of ingested radiolabelled vitamin B12 even with normal absorption-False positive results.

Reference: Wintrobe's, 11th ed, Pg-1386)

questions.text: Direct coombs test detects?
questions.solution:
The direct coombs test is used to detect antibodies that are stuck to the surface of red blood cells.

Reference: (Robbins Basic Pathology, 8th ed, Pg-653)

questions.text: All of the following cancers are associated with Disseminated Intravascular Bleeding Except?
questions.solution:
Cancers associated with DIC are: Ca pancreas, Ca lung, Acute promyelocytic leukemia, Ca prostate, Ca stomach.

Reference:(Robbins Basic Pathology, 8th ed, Pg-673)

questions.text: The classification proposed by the International Lymphoma Study Group for non-hodgkin's lymphoma is known as-
questions.solution:
In 1994, a group of hemopathologist, oncologist and molecular biologist came together (International Lymphoma Study Group) and introduced a new classification, called the 'Revised European- American Classification of lymphoid Neoplasms (REAL).

Reference: (Robbins Basic Pathology, 7th ed, Pg-668)

questions.text: Which amongst following is not a feature of multiple myeloma?
questions.solution:
In multiple myeloma, Bone resorption often leads to pathologic fractures and chronic pain. The attendant hypercalcemia can give rise to neurologic manifestations, such as confusion, weakness, and lethargy, and contributes to renal dysfunction. Bone resorption is not associated with increased osteoblastic activity, so alkaline phosphate is not raised.

Reference: (Robbins Basic Pathology, 10th ed, Pg-472-73)

choices.text: Occurs when donor cells are immunocompromised
A common cause is stem cell transplantation

questions.text: Which of the following statement about graft versus host reaction is least correct?
questions.solution:
Graft versus host disease occurs when immunologically competent donor cells (not immunocompromised donor cells) are transplanted into immunologically crippled (immunocompromised) host and transferred cells recognize host cells as alloantigens.

Reference:(Robbins Basic Pathology, 8th ed, Pg-230)

questions.text: Which amongst the following is obstructive lung disease?
questions.solution:
Obstructive lung disease have the four disorders in this group-emphysema, chronic bronchitis, asthma, and bronchiectasis.

Emphysema is characterized by permanent enlargement of the air spaces distal to the terminal bronchioles, accompanied by destruction of their walls without significant fibrosis.

Reference: (Robbins Basic Pathology, 10th ed, Pg-498)

questions.text: Which type of anemia is associated with leukemia?
questions.solution:
Myelophthisic anemia is caused by extensive infiltration of the marrow by tumors or other lesions. It most commonly is associated with metastatic breast, lung, or prostate cancer. The principal manifestations include anemia and thrombocytopenia; in general, the white cell series is less affected. Characteristically misshapen red cells, some resembling teardrops, are seen in the peripheral blood. Immature granulocytic and erythrocytic precursors also may be present (leukoerythroblastosis) along with mild leucocytosis.

Reference: (Robbins Basic Pathology, 10th ed, Pg-458)

questions.text: Which of the following follows Reid index?
questions.solution:
Chronic bronchitis is diagnosed on clinical grounds: it is defined by the presence of a persistent productive cough for at least 3 consecutive months in at least 2 consecutive years. Reid index is used to assess the increase in the size of the submucus gland in chronic bronchitis.

The diagnostic feature of chronic bronchitis in the trachea and larger bronchi is enlargement of the mucussecreting glands. The magnitude of the increase in size is assessed by the ratio of the thickness of the submucosal gland layer to that of the bronchial wall (the Reid index - normally 0.4).

Reference: (Robbins Basic Pathology, 10thed, Pg-502

questions.text: Pleural mesothelioma is associated with?
questions.solution:
Malignant mesothelioma has assumed great importance because it is highly related to exposure to airborne asbestos. It is a rare cancer of mesothelial cells, usually arising in the parietal or visceral pleura; it also occurs much less commonly in the peritoneum and pericardium. Those who work directly with asbestos (shipyard workers, miners, insulators) are at greatest risk, but malignant mesotheliomas have appeared in individuals whose only exposure was living in proximity to an asbestos factory or being a relative of an asbestos worker.

Reference: (Robbins Basic Pathology, 10th ed, Pg-545)

questions.text: In reflux nephropathy, glomerular lesion is-
questions.solution:
Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS) is characterized by sclerosis of some (but not all) glomeruli that involves only a part of each affected glomerulus. FSGS may be primary (idiopathic) or secondary to one of the following conditions:

  • HIV infection (HIV nephropathy). FSGS is seen in 5-10% of patients infected with HIV, but the incidence is decreasing with improved antiviral therapy.
  • Heroin abuse (heroin nephropathy)
  • Secondary to other forms of GN (e.g., IgA nephropathy)
  • As a maladaptation to nephron loss. Inherited forms, including autosomal dominant forms associated with mutations in cytoskeletal proteins and podocin, both of which are required for the integrity of podocytes.

Reference: (Robbin's, 8th ed, Pg-926)

questions.text: Which is he most constant and persistent feature of carcinoma bladder?
questions.solution:
Painless hematuria is the most common presenting symptom. It may be gross or microscopic, intermittent rather continuous. Symptoms of visceral irritability are second most common- Frequency, urgency, dysuria.

Pain may occur rarely due to secondary clot retention, tumour extension into retroperitoneum, ureteric obstruction or metastasis to bony pelvis.

Reference: (Robbins Basic Pathology, 8th ed, Pg-980)

questions.text: Which cell does not secrete Mucin?
questions.solution:
Panth cells are specific type of cells within crypt of liberkuhn.

These cells have atypically oriented bright eosinophilic granules containing a variety of antimicrobial proteins and play a role in mucosal immunity (and not mucin secretion).

Reference: (Robbins Basic Pathology, 7th ed, Pg-829)

questions.text: Which of the following is associated with toxic megacolon?
questions.solution: Reference: (Robbins Basic Pathology, 10th ed, Pg-622)

questions.text: Which of the following does not show normal liver histology?
questions.solution:
Hemochromatosis is caused by excessive absoprtion of iron, which is primarily deposited in parenchymal organs such as the liver and pancreas, as well as in the heart, joints, and endocrine organs. The morphologic changes in severe hemochromatosis are characterized principally by

  1. tissue deposition of hemosiderin in the following organs (in decreasing order of severity): liver, pancreas, myocardium, pituitary gland, adrenal gland, thyroid and parathyroid glands, joints, and skin;
  2. cirrhosis; and
  3. pancreatic fibrosis. In the liver, iron becomes evident first as golden-yellow hemosiderin granules in the cytoplasm of periportal hepatocytes, which can be histochemically stained with Prussian blue.

Reference: (Robbins Basic Pathology, 10th ed, Pg-657)

questions.text: Which of the following is associated with Angiosarcoma of liver?
questions.solution:
Angiosarcoma of liver is associated with the exposure of: Vinyl chloride, Arsenic and thortrast.

Reference: (Robbins Basic Pathology, 8thed, Pg-878-879)

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common site for carcinoma Pancreas?
questions.solution:
Infiltrating ductal adenocarcinoma of the pancreas (more commonly referred to as pancreatic cancer) is the third leading cause of cancer deaths in the United States, preceded only by lung and colon cancers. Approximately 60% of pancreatic cancers arise in the head of the gland, 15% in the body, and 5% in the tail; in the remaining 20%, the neoplasm diffusely involves the entire organ.

Reference: (Robbins Basic Pathology, 10th ed, Pg-688)

questions.text: Which of the following shows testicular movement without epididymitis?
questions.solution:
Inflammation is more common in epididymis than in testis. Of the three major inflammatory states, gonorrhoea and TB almost invariably arise in epididymis; whereas syphilis affects testis first. Granuloma inguinale affects external genital organs (not testis and epididymis).

Reference: (Robbins, 8th ed, Pg-968)

questions.text: Which of the following is responsible for the prostatic growth in benign prostatic hypertrophy?
questions.solution:
DHT (Dihydrotestosterone), a metabolite of testosterone is the ultimate mediator for prostatic growth.

Reference:(Robbins, 8th ed, Pg-995)

questions.text: The largest ovarian tumour is seen with-
questions.solution:
Mucinous tumor tends to produce larger cystic masses, and some have been recorded with the weight of more than 25 kgs.

Reference:(Robbins, 8th ed, Pg-1044)

questions.text: Women carrying BRACA 1 gene are more likely to develop -
questions.solution:
Medullary carcinomas and mucinous carcinomas histological types are more commonly found in BRACA1 carrier.

Reference:(Robbins, 8th ed, Pg-1077)

questions.text: What does involucrum means?
questions.solution:
In osteomyelitis

Sequestrum- The dead piece of bone

Involucrum- Reactive woven or lamellar bone around sequestrum.

Reference:(Robbins, 8th ed, Pg-1222)

questions.text: Which of the following bone tumour is hormone dependent?
questions.solution:
Polyostotic fibrous dysplasia is associated with endocrine abnormalities.

Reference:(Robbins, 8th ed, Pg-1231)

questions.text: Which of the following produce complex granular corpuscle?
questions.solution:
Complex granular corpuscle are produced by microglia.

Reference:(Dorland, 28th ed, Pg-328)

questions.text: Struge weber syndrome is associated with?
questions.solution:
Features of sturge weber syndrome:

Unilateral facial nerve (port wine stain) on upper face and eyelid.

Cavernous hemangioma

Seizures

Hemiparesis

Stroke like episode

Visual defects

Buphthalmos and glaucoma

Mental retardation

Pheochromocytoma

Reference: (Robbins, 8th ed, Pg-522)

questions.text: Common spinal cord tumour with intradural but extramedullary situation-
questions.solution:
Spinal cord tumour:


Reference: (Bailey and love, 24th ed,Pg-574)

questions.text: In which thyroid carcinoma, FNAC is least diagnostic?
questions.solution:
FNAC is the best investigation for the diagnosis of all thyroid cancers except follicular carcinoma. Follicular carcinoma shows vascular and capsular invasion.

Reference: (Robbins Basic Pathology, 8th ed, Pg-1123)

questions.text: From which of the followings pheochromocytoma does not arise?
questions.solution:
Pheochromocytoma is a neoplasm of chromaffin cells which usually arise from adrenal medulla.

About 10% of these tumors arise at extradrenal sites, where they are called paragangliomas.

Reference: (Robbins Basic Pathology, 8th ed, Pg-1159)

questions.text: Which of the following is the marker of melanoma?
questions.solution: The markers to see the spread of malignant melanoma are: S-100 and TA-90.

questions.text: In which of the following civatte bodies are found?
questions.solution:
'Pruritic, purple, polygonal, planar papules, and plaques' are the tongue-twisting Ps that describe this disorder of skin and squamous mucosa. The lesions may result from a CD8+ T cell - mediated cytotoxic response against antigens in the basal cell layer and the dermoepidermal junction that are produced by unknown mechanisms.

Anucleate, necrotic basal cells are seen in the inflamed papillary dermis and are referred to as colloid bodies or Civatte bodies.

Reference: (Robbins Basic Pathology, 10th ed, Pg-893)

questions.text: Durcks granuloma is seen in-
questions.solution:
Durcks granuloma - Ring haemorrhages and focal inflammatory reaction seen in brain in cerebral malaria caused by p. falciparum.

Reference: (Robbins Basic Pathology, 8th ed, Pg-388)

questions.text: Warthin-Finkeldey giant cells are seen in-
questions.solution:
Warthin-Finkeldey cells are multinucleated giant cells.

These cells are pathognomic of measles and are found in lymphoid organs, lung and sputum.

Reference: (Robbins Basic Pathology, 8thed, Pg-350)

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common tumor of infancy?
questions.solution:
Hemangioma is the most common benign tumour of infancy. It occurs in 10% of term infant.

Reference:(Robbins Basic Pathology, 8thed, Pg-473)

questions.text: Which is the anticoagulant of choice for ESR by wintrobe's method?
questions.solution:
Anticoagulant of choice for ESR:

Wintrobes method - Double oxalate and EDTA

Westergen method - Sodium citrate

Reference: (Clinial haematology by Stiene - Martin, Lotspiech, Steininger, 2thed, Pg-118)

questions.text: Occular basement membrane is stained by-
questions.solution:
Basement membranes are periodic acid schiff's (PAS) positive amorphous structure that lie underneath epithelia of different organs.

Reference: (Harsh Mohan, 5th ed, Pg-238)

questions.text: Reverse cholesterol transport is mediated by-
questions.solution:
Cholesterol may be derived from the diet or from endogenous synthesis. Dietary triglycerides and cholesterol are incorporated into chylomicrons in the intestinal mucosa and travel by way of the gut lymphatics to the blood.

As shown below, Low-density lipoprotein (LDL) metabolism and the role of the liver in its synthesis and clearance. Lipolysis of very-low-density lipoprotein (VLDL) by lipoprotein lipase in the capillaries releases triglycerides, which are then stored in fat cells and used as a source of energy in skeletal muscles. IDL (intermediate-density lipoprotein) remains in the blood and is taken up by the liver


Reference: (Robbins Basic Pathology, 10th ed, Pg-248-249)

questions.text: Gamma gandy bodies are seen in?
questions.solution:
Gamma gandy bodies - These are foci of fibrosis containing iron and calcium salts deposits on connective tissue and elastic fibres.

Gamma gandy bodies are seen in congestive splenomegaly eg. In sickle cell anemia, Chronic myeloid leukemia and cirrhosis.

Reference: (Robbins Basic Pathology, 7th ed, Pg-705)

questions.text: Budd chiari syndrome can be caused by all except?
questions.solution:
The obstruction of two or more major hepatic veins produces liver enlargement, pain, and ascites, a condition known as Budd-Chiari syndrome. Obstruction of a single main hepatic vein by thrombosis is clinically silent. Hepatic damage is the consequence of increased intrahepatic blood pressure. Hepatic vein thrombosis is associated with the same hypercoagulable states as portal vein thrombosis as well as intraabdominal cancers, particularly HCC. Budd-Chiari syndrome often occurs in patients with several risk factors, such as pregnancy or oral contraceptive use combined with an underlying thrombophilic disorder.

Reference: (Robbins Basic Pathology, 10th ed, Pg-667)

questions.text: A ganglionic segment is encountered in which part of colon in a case of Hirschsprung disease?
questions.solution:
Hirschsprung disease occurs in approximately 1 of 5000 live births and stems from a congenital defect in colonic innervation. The enteric neuronal plexus develops from neural crest cells that migrate into the bowel wall during embryogenesis. Hirschsprung disease, also known as congenital aganglionic megacolon, results when the normal migration of neural crest cells from cecum to rectum is disrupted. This produces a distal intestinal segment that lacks both the Meissner submucosal plexus and the Auerbach myenteric plexus ('aganglionosis'), and thus fails to develop coordinated peristaltic contractions. Mutations in the receptor tyrosine kinase RET account for a majority of familial cases and approximately 15% of sporadic cases.

Reference: (Robbins Basic Pathology, 10th ed, Pg-608)

questions.text: Red infarct is seen in?
questions.solution:
Red infarcts occur

  1. as a result of venous occlusions (such as in ovarian torsion);
  2. in loose tissues (e.g., lung) where blood can collect in infarcted zones;
  3. in tissues with dual circulations such as lung and small intestine, where partial, albeit inadequate perfusion by collateral arterial supplies is typical;
  4. in previously congested tissues (as a consequence of sluggish venous outflow); and
  5. when flow is reestablished after infarction has occurred (e.g., after angioplasty of an arterial obstruction).

Reference: (Robbins Basic Pathology, 10th ed, Pg-114-15)
